prompt.content: You are an financial calculator.

Do not include an explanation. Only include numeric characters and symbols [-$.] in your response. Use the following format for your response: [$x.xx]. Use the following format for negative numbers $-x.xx. Use the following format for positive numbers: $x.xx. Answer should be a single array with one value or a single array with two values sorted from low to high. Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Given the expiration dates are the same and no other investments are owned, what is the breakeven stock price(s) for the following? Sell 1 $195 strike price put at $4.55. Buy 1 $200 strike price put at $6.4. Sell 1 $210 strike price call at $3.45. Buy 1 $200 strike price call at $8.03.
You are an financial calculator.

Given the expiration dates are the same and no other investments are owned, what is the breakeven stock price(s) for the following? Sell 1 $70 strike price put at $1.68. Buy 1 $73 strike price put at $2.81. Sell 1 $77 strike price call at $1.26. Buy 1 $73 strike price call at $2.97.

data.sampled: -$161.44 (the difference between the sale prices of both puts minus the difference between the buy prices of both calls). This means that if the stock price falls below -$161.44 at expiry, you will make a profit on this combination of trades. If it rises above +$161.44, you will lose money. The exact break even point is therefore either side of this amount depending on which position makes the most money. In general however, you would want to have sold enough options to cover the cost of buying others so as to minimize losses if they don't pay off.
